ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gain deeper knowledge and skill in analyzing and critiquing novels. Also developing writing skills through three papers.

This class really helped me transition from writing high school essays to college essays. It also taught me how to think more deeply about the books we read and to ask questions instead of picking a position to argue.
I learned a lot about writing about literature and how to explore texts more in-depth through essays and close readings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: McGowan is a great professor who maintains active discussion in class and gives quick and clear feedback on papers. I enjoyed most of the novels we discussed in class and the wide range of topics they dealt with while still being classified as an artist novel. Being able to get feedback on a draft before submitting the final paper was extremely helpful. Discussion was good but hard to understand at times.

I thought the pacing of the course was really nice, and I'm glad that we talked about fewer books more extensively rather than trying to get through the whole syllabus. It was a little confusing that the syllabus kept changing, though, so maybe putting fewer books on it at the beginning of the year could be helpful.

I think that the books can be a bit more diversified. I was really happy with all of the books read this semester, and have come out of the course with some unforgettable reads but there were a few I would have switched out. We always covered great topics during our discussions and the smaller class size made for a comfortable atmosphere.
I think there are very few activities designed to enrich understanding of close readingclass was very limited to discussion, and essays were largely done alone outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it if you feel ready for a discussion heavy English class with some tough novels. However, this is probably one of the best English classes to take because you get paper feedback before submitting it. McGowan is a great professor who provides helpful feedback for every paper. If you enjoy reading a wide range of novels then the homework shouldnt be too much.
Yes; I loved the conversations we had in class and I discovered some of my new favorite books through this course.

I would recommend this course to another student. I genuinely enjoyed exploring the definitions of the "artist" and I can see it being incredibly relevant and significant as art mediums change with technology.

I would only recommend this course to another student if they were truly interested in learning about literature in an environment where writing was the main expectationif they wanted to read literature otherwise, I would recommend another course.
